sen.j: 月見（つきみ）とは、満月など月を眺めて楽しむこと。
sen.e: Tsukimi is to enjoy viewing the moon such as the full moon.
Tsukimi is to enjoy viewing the moon, such as the full moon.
Tsukimi is to enjoy viewing the moon, such as the full moon.

sen.j: 観月（かんげつ）とも言う。
sen.e: It is also called Kangetsu.
It is also called kangetsu.
It is also called Kangetsu.
sen.cmt: 観月を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 狭義には、太陰太陽暦（旧暦）の8月15日 (旧暦)（十五夜）と9月13日 (旧暦)（十三夜）の夜の月見を指す。
sen.e: In a limited sense, it implies Tsukimi on the nights of August 15th (the Fifteenth Night) and September 13th (the Thirteenth Night) of the lunar calendar (old calendar).
sen.cmt: 日付のあとの２回の（旧暦）は不要と判断しました。
sen.e: In a limited sense, it implies tsukimi on the nights of August 15th (the fifteenth night) and September 13th (the thirteenth night) of the lunar calendar (old calendar).
In a limited sense, it implies Tsukimi on the nights of August 15 (the fifteenth night) and September 13 (the thirteenth night) of the lunar calendar (old calendar).
sen.cmt: 月見を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 旧暦の8月15日を「中秋」と呼ぶため「中秋の名月（ちゅうしゅうのめいげつ）」ともいう。
sen.e: August 15th of the old calendar is called "Chushu (中秋)," so it is also called "Chushu no Meigetsu (中秋の名月)."
August 15th of the old calendar is called "Chushu (中秋)," so it is also called "Chushu no Meigetsu (中秋の名月)."
August 15th of the old calendar is called "Chushu (中秋)," so it is also called "Chushu no Meigetsu (中秋の名月)."

sen.j: また、旧暦8月は、秋（7月から9月）のちょうど中頃なので「仲秋」と呼ぶため「仲秋の名月（ちゅうしゅうのめいげつ）」と表記する場合もあるが、「中秋」は旧暦8月15日をさし、「仲秋」は秋を三つに区分したときの真ん中の期間をさす言葉であるので、「中秋の名月」が正しい表記である。
sen.e: It is also referred as "仲秋の名月" sometimes, since August of the old calendar is right in the middle of Fall (from July to September) and is called "仲秋," but "中秋" indicates August 15th of the old calendar and "仲秋" indicates the middle period when separating Fall into three, so "中秋の名月" is the correct expression.

It is also occasionally referred to as "仲秋の名月," since August of the old calendar is right in the middle of fall (from July to September) and is called "仲秋," but "中秋" indicates August 15th of the old calendar and "仲秋" indicates the middle period when separating fall into three, so "中秋の名月" is the correct expression.

It is also occasionally referred to as "仲秋の名月," since August of the old calendar is right in the middle of fall (from July to September) and is called "仲秋," but "中秋" indicates August 15th of the old calendar and "仲秋" indicates the middle period when separating fall into three, so "中秋の名月" is the correct expression.

sen.j: 十五夜のグレゴリオ暦（新暦）での該当日はこちらの8月15日 (旧暦)対照表を参照。
sen.e: See this reference table of August 15th (old calendar) for the corresponding date of the Fifteenth Night in the Gregorian calendar (new calendar).
See this reference table of August 15th (old calendar) for the corresponding date of the fifteenth night in the Gregorian calendar (new calendar).
See this reference table of August 15th (old calendar) for the corresponding date of the fifteenth night in the Gregorian calendar (new calendar).

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Overview
Overview
Summary

sen.j: 古来より8月 (旧暦)（グレゴリオ暦（新暦）では9月ごろ）は、空気が乾燥して月が鮮やかに見え、かつ、湿度も低く夜でもそれほど寒くないため、観月に最も良い時節とされていた。
sen.e: Since ancient times, in August in the old calendar (in around September in the Gregorian calendar as the new calendar), the air is dry and the moon is clearly seen, and it is not too cold even at night with lower humidity, it has been regarded as the best timing for the moon viewing.

Since ancient times, in August of the old calendar (around September in the newer Gregorian calendar), the air is dry and the moon is clearly seen, and it is not too cold even at night with lower humidity; this has been regarded as the best time of year for moon viewing.

Since ancient times, in August of the old calendar (around September in the newer Gregorian calendar), the air is dry and the moon is clearly seen, and it is not too cold even at night with lower humidity; this has been regarded as the best time of year for moon viewing.

sen.j: この夜は、月が見える場所などに祭壇を作りススキ（すすき）を飾って月見団子・里芋・枝豆・クリなどを盛り、御酒を供えて月を眺めた（お月見料理）、豊作を祈る満月法会など。
sen.e: On the night, an altar is set where the moon is visible, and Japanese pampas grass is decorated and Tsukimi Dango dumplings, sato-imo (taro), edamame (green soybeans) or chestnuts are put, and sake is offered, in which way people enjoy viewing the moon (moon viewing dishes), such as a Buddhist service for the full moon to pray for good harvest.

On the night, an altar is set where the moon is visible, and Japanese pampas grass is decorated and tsukimi dango dumplings, sato-imo (taro), edamame (green soybeans) or chestnuts are put out, and sake is offered, in which way people enjoy viewing the moon (moon-viewing dishes), such as in a Buddhist service for the full moon to pray for a good harvest.

That night, an altar is set up in a place from which the moon is visible; it is decorated with Japanese pampas grass, and Tsukimi Dango dumplings, sato-imo (taro), edamame (green soybeans) or chestnuts are put out, and sake is offered, in which way people enjoy viewing the moon (moon-viewing dishes), such as in a Buddhist service for the full moon in order to pray for a good harvest.
sen.cmt: 月見団子を大文字にしました。

sen.j: このことから芋名月とも言う。
sen.e: For this reason, it is also called Imo Meigetsu.
For this reason, it is also called "imo meigetsu."
For this reason, it is also called Imo Meigetsu.
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションをとりました。（原稿どおりの表記に）

sen.j: 中国でも同様の習慣があるが、仲秋節として日本より盛大に祝い月餅を作って供物する。
sen.e: China has the similar custom, but they celebrate in a greater way then Japan as Mid-Autumn Festival, and Moon Cakes are made and offered.
China has a similar custom, but they celebrate in a greater way then Japan as the Mid-Autumn Festival, and moon cakes are made and offered.
China has a similar custom, but they celebrate in a greater way than Japan as the Mid-Autumn Festival, and moon cakes are made and offered.

sen.j: この月餅が日本に伝わって、月見団子に変ったという。
sen.e: It is said that the Moon Cakes were introduced to Japan and changed into Tsukimi Dango dumplings.
It is said that the moon cakes were introduced to Japan and changed into tsukimi dango dumplings.
It is said that the moon cakes were introduced to Japan and changed into Tsukimi Dango dumplings.
sen.cmt: 月見団子を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 大韓民国でも、この時期、月見の習慣があり、チュソク（秋夕）といい、勤めも休みになり、郷里で親族と共に祝うお正月、お盆に次ぐお祭りになっている。
sen.e: Republic of Korea also has the custom of moon viewing around this time, which is called Chuseok, and it is the third biggest festival next to the New Year and Lantern Festival to celebrate with families at hometown.

The Republic of Korea also has the custom of moon viewing around this time, which is called Chuseok, and it is the third-biggest festival next to the New Year and Lantern Festival to celebrate with families in one's hometown.

The Republic of Korea also has the custom of moon viewing around this time, which is called Chuseok; it's the third-biggest festival next to the New Year and Lantern Festival as holidays from work to celebrate with families in one's hometown.
sen.cmt: 「勤めも休みになり」の部分の訳を補いました。

sen.j: ソンピョン（松餅）というお菓子をつくる。
sen.e: Cakes called Songpyeon are made.
Cakes called songpyeon are made.
Cakes called songpyeon are made.

sen.j: 十三夜は日本独自の風習であり、ちょうど食べ頃の大豆やクリなどを供えることから、この夜の月を豆名月または栗名月という。
sen.e: The Thirteenth Night is a Japanese original custom, and the moon of the night is called Mame Meigetsu or Kuri Meigetsu since beans (Mame) and chestnuts (Kuri) in season are offered.
The "thirteenth night" is an original Japanese custom, and the moon of the night is called "mame meigetsu" or "kuri meigetsu," since beans (mame) and chestnuts (kuri) in season are offered.
The Thirteenth Night is an original Japanese custom, and the moon of the night is called Mame Meigetsu or Kuri Meigetsu, since beans (mame) and chestnuts (kuri) in season are offered.
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションをとりました。（原稿どおりの表記に）豆、栗を大文字に。

sen.j: 十五夜と十三夜どちらか片方の月見しかしないのは「片月見」または「片見月」と言って嫌われた。
sen.e: Viewing either of the moon of the Fifteenth Night or the Thirteenth Night is called "Katatsukimi (single moon-viewing)" or "Katamitsuki (the moon of single viewing)," which was disfavored.

Viewing the moon on either the fifteenth night or the thirteenth night is called "katatsukimi (single moon-viewing)" or "katamitsuki (the moon of single viewing)," which has historically been less favorable.

Viewing the moon on either the fifteenth night or the thirteenth night is called "katatsukimi (single moon-viewing)" or "katamitsuki (the moon of single viewing)," which has historically been less favorable.

sen.j: そのため、二度目のデートを確実に行うために、十五夜に異性を誘う（相手はどうしても十三夜にも来なければならないため）、ということがあったようだ。
sen.e: Therefore, in order to have the second date for sure, it is said that some people invited the opposite sex on the Fifteenth Night (the invited person must come to the Thirteenth Night as well).

Therefore, in order to have the second date for sure, it is said that some people would invite someone of the opposite sex on the fifteenth night (the invited person must come to the thirteenth night as well).

Therefore, in order to have the second date for sure, it is said that some people would invite someone of the opposite sex on the fifteenth night (the invited person must come to the thirteenth night as well).

sen.j: 更に、地方によっては月待ちという風習があり、十七夜以降を立待月（たてまち-）、居待月（いまち-）、寝待月（ねまち-）、更待月（ふけまち-）、というのはこの名残である。
sen.e: Furthermore, some regions had a custom called moon-waiting, which is why the moon after the Seventeenth Night is called Tatemachi-zuki (moon-waiting in a standing position), Imachi-zuki (moon-waiting in a sitting position), Nemachi-zuki (moon-waiting in a lying position) and Fukemachi-zuki (moon-waiting late at night).

Furthermore, some regions had a custom called moon-waiting, which is why the moon after the seventeenth night is called "tatemachi-zuki (moon-waiting in a standing position)," "imachi-zuki (moon-waiting in a sitting position)," "nemachi-zuki (moon-waiting in a lying position)" and "fukemachi-zuki (moon-waiting late at night)."

Furthermore, some regions had a custom called moon-waiting, which is why the moon after the seventeenth night is called Tatemachi-zuki (moon-waiting in a standing position), Imachi-zuki (moon-waiting in a sitting position), Nemachi-zuki (moon-waiting in a lying position) and Fukemachi-zuki (moon-waiting late at night).
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションをとりました。（原稿どおりの表記に）

sen.j: 二十三夜待ちまでを行う地域が多くを占めたが、二十六夜待ちまで行う地域があり、月光に阿弥陀仏・観音菩薩・勢至菩薩の三尊が現れる（広辞苑より）、という口実を付けて月が昇る（大体、深夜二時ごろ）まで遊興にふけった。
sen.e: Most regions had moon-waiting until the Twenty-third Night, but some had until the Twenty-sixth Night, and people pursued pleasure until the moon rose (around two o'clock midnight) on the excuse that three deities, Amida Buddha, Kannon Bodhisattva and Seishi Bodhisattva would appear in the moonlight (from Japanese dictionary Kojien).

Most regions would have the moon-waiting until the twenty-third night, but some had until the twenty-sixth night, and people pursued pleasure until the moon rose (around two o'clock midnight) on the excuse that three deities--Amida Buddha, Kannon Bodhisattva and Seishi Bodhisattva--would appear in the moonlight (from the Japanese dictionary "Kojien").

Most regions would have the moon-waiting until the twenty-third night, but some had it until the twenty-sixth night, and people pursued pleasure until the moon rose (around two o'clock in the morning) on the excuse that three deities--Amida Buddha, Kannon Bodhisattva and Seishi Bodhisattva--would appear in the moonlight (from the Japanese dictionary "Kojien").
sen.cmt: 文法間違い。 “had until”=>”had it until” midnightの意味は午前零時。翻訳間違い。 “two o'clock midnight”=>”two o'clock in the morning”

sen.j: この風習は明治時代に入ると急速に廃れていったようだ。
sen.e: This custom seems to have rapidly died out in the Meiji era.
Apparently, this custom faded quickly in the Meiji era.
Apparently, this custom faded quickly in the Meiji period.

sen.j: 中国、日本では、月を愛でるという習慣が古くからあり、日本では縄文時代ごろからあるといわれ平安時代ごろから中国から月見の祭事が伝わると貴族などの間で観月の宴や舟遊び（直接月を見るのではなく船などにのったりして水面に揺れる月を楽しむ）など歌を詠んだり酒を飲んだりした。
sen.e: China and Japan has had the custom to appreciate the moon from ancient times, and especially in Japan, it is said that the custom has existed since the Jomon era, and after the festival of moon viewing was introduced from China around the Heian era, the nobles had Kangetsu parties and boating parties (to enjoy the reflection of the moon swinging on the water surface from a boat, instead of viewing the moon directly) with composing poems and drinking.

China and Japan have had the custom of appreciating the moon since ancient times, and particularly in Japan it is said that the custom has existed since the Jomon era; after the festival of moon viewing was introduced from China around the Heian era, the nobles had kangetsu parties and boating parties (to enjoy the reflection of the moon swinging on the water surface from a boat, instead of viewing the moon directly) in which they would compose poems and enjoy drinking.

China and Japan have had the custom of appreciating the moon since ancient times, and particularly in Japan it is said that the custom has existed since the Jomon period; after the festival of moon viewing was introduced from China around the Heian period, the nobles had Kangetsu parties and boating parties (to enjoy the reflection of the moon swinging on the water surface from a boat, instead of viewing the moon directly) in which they would compose poems and enjoy drinking.
sen.cmt: 観月を大文字にしました。era→periodに変更しました。

sen.j: ヨーロッパでは満月は人の心をかき乱し、狂わせるものであったようで、月の女神が死を暗示したり、狼男が月を見て変身するというのは、その典型的な例で、とても月を眺めて楽しむという気分にはなれなかったようだ。
sen.e: In Europe, it seems that the full moon was supposed to disturb and confuse people's mind, and as the typical examples, the goddess of the moon indicates death, and a werewolf transforms himself by seeing the moon, so they did not feel like enjoying viewing the moon at all.

In Europe, it seems that the full moon was supposed to disturb and confuse people's minds; for example, the goddess of the moon indicates death, and a werewolf transforms himself by seeing the moon, so people did not want to view the moon at all.

In Europe, it seems that the full moon was supposed to disturb and confuse people's minds; for example, the goddess of the moon indicates death, and a werewolf transforms himself by seeing the moon, so people did not want to view the moon at all.

sen.j: 日本でも『竹取物語』に、月を眺めるかぐや姫を嫗が注意する場面があるため、中国から観月の風習が入る前はヨーロッパと似た考えを月に対して持っていたようだ。
sen.e: In Japan, "The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter" has a scene that the old woman warns Lady Kaguya seeing the moon, which implies that they had a similar idea with Europe before the custom of moon viewing was introduced from China.

In Japan, "The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter" has a scene in which the old woman warns Lady Kaguya about seeing the moon, which implies that they had an idea similar to that of Europe before the custom of moon viewing was introduced from China.

In Japan, "The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter" has a scene in which the old woman warns Lady Kaguya about seeing the moon, which implies that they had an idea similar to that of Europe before the custom of moon viewing was introduced from China.

sen.j: 月月に月見る月は多けれど 月見る月はこの月の月（「月」が8回あり、「この月」が8月であることを示している）
sen.e: You can see the moon in many months, but the best month to see the moon is this month. (This has eight times of the Chinese character to mean the moon and also month, which shows 'this month' means August.)

You can see the moon in many months, but the best month to see the moon is this month. (This has eight times the Chinese characters to mean the moon and also the month, which shows that 'this month' means August.)

sen.j: ゆでた蕎麦・うどんを丼に入れ、場合によって群雲（むらくも）に見立てた海苔を敷いてから、生卵を割り入れて、汁と薬味を添えたものを「月見うどん」、「月見そば」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: Boiled soba (buckwheat noodles) and udon (wheat noodles) put in a bowl, and sometimes after putting nori (dried seaweed) to resemble gathering clouds, cracking a raw egg into it and adding soup and condiments, are called "Tsukimi soba" and "Tsukimi udon" respectively.

Boiled soba (buckwheat noodles) and udon (wheat noodles) put in a bowl, and sometimes after putting nori (dried seaweed) to resemble gathering clouds, cracking a raw egg into it and adding soup and condiments, are called "Tsukimi soba" and "Tsukimi udon," respectively.

Boiled soba (buckwheat noodles) and udon (wheat noodles) put in a bowl, and sometimes after putting nori (dried seaweed) to resemble gathering clouds, cracking a raw egg into it and adding soup and condiments, are called "Tsukimi soba" and "Tsukimi udon," respectively.

sen.j: 月見の風情をどんぶりの中に見立てたものである。
sen.e: This resembles the atmosphere of Tsukimi in a bowl.
This resembles the atmosphere of tsukimi in a bowl.
This resembles the atmosphere of tsukimi in a bowl.

sen.j: 本来、月見に海苔は必須であり、海苔なしの場合は「玉（ぎょく）」といったが（「玉（ぎょく）落とし」「玉（ぎょく）入り」「玉（ぎょく）落ち」等）、しかし現代では海苔なしでも卵さえ入っていれば月見といってしまうことも多い。
sen.e: Originally, Nori was a must in Tsukimi noodles, and ones without it were called 'Gyoku' ('Gyoku otoshi,' 'Gyoku iri' or 'Gyoku ochi'), but today, ones only with an egg without nori are called Tsukimi in most cases.

Originally, nori was a must in tsukimi noodles, and ones without it were called 'gyoku' ('gyoku otoshi,' 'gyoku iri' or 'gyoku ochi'); but today, ones with just an egg but no nori are usually called tsukimi.

Originally, nori was a must in Tsukimi noodles, and ones without it were called 'Gyoku' ('gyoku otoshi,' 'Gyoku iri' or 'Gyoku ochi'); but today, ones with just an egg but no nori are usually called Tsukimi.

sen.j: 鍋焼きうどんや味噌煮込みうどんにも鶏卵を割り入れる場合も多いが、火が通って黄身が見えにくくなるためか、月見とは呼ばれない。
sen.e: Nabeyaki udon or Miso-nikomi udon also has a raw egg cracked in most cases, but it is not called Tsukimi, probably because the cooked yolk cannot be seen well.
Nabeyaki udon or miso-nikomi udon also has a raw egg cracked into it in most cases, but it is not called tsukimi, probably because the cooked yolk isn't readily visible.
Nabeyaki udon or Miso-nikomi udon also has a raw egg cracked into it in most cases, but it is not called Tsukimi, probably because the cooked yolk isn't readily visible.
sen.cmt: 味噌煮込み、月見を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 北九州市では、焼きうどんなどにくぼみを作り、中に卵を落として、ひっくり返して焼いたものを天窓と称している。
sen.e: In Kita Kyushu City, there is a dish called Tenmado (skylight window), that noodles such as Yaki udon with an egg dropped into a dent are overturned and broiled.
In Kita Kyushu City there is a dish called tenmado (skylight window), in which noodles such as yaki udon with an egg dropped into a dent are overturned and broiled.
In Kita Kyushu City there is a dish called Tenmado (skylight window), in which noodles such as yaki udon with an egg dropped into a dent are overturned and broiled.
sen.cmt: 天窓、焼きうどんを大文字にしました。

sen.j: これは天窓から月が見える様子を言っており、月見の変型である。
sen.e: This resembles the picture of the moon from a skylight window, which is another version of Tsukimi noodles.
This resembles the picture of the moon from a skylight window, which is another version of tsukimi noodles.
This resembles the picture of the moon from a skylight window, which is another version of Tsukimi noodles.
sen.cmt: 月見を大文字にしました。

sen.j: マクドナルドでは1991年以来、秋限定メニューとして、9月から10月にかけて目玉焼きの入った「月見バーガー」を発売している。
sen.e: McDonald has sold a 'Tsukimi burger' with an egg sunny-side up from September to October as a special fall menu since 1991.
McDonald's has sold a 'tsukimi burger' with an egg sunny-side up from September to October as a special fall menu item since 1991.
McDonald's has, since 1991, sold a 'Tsukimi burger' with an egg sunny-side up from September to October as a special fall menu item.
sen.cmt: 月見を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 台湾では、かき氷のメニューのひとつとして「月見冰 ユエチエンピン」（月見氷）がある。
sen.e: In Taiwan, as a shaved ice menu, they have '月見冰, Yue jian bing' (Tsukimi Ice).
In Taiwan, as a shaved-ice item, they have '月見冰, yue jian bing' (tsukimi ice).'
In Taiwan, as a shaved-ice item, they have '月見冰, yue jian bing' (Tsukimi ice).'
sen.cmt: 月見を大文字にしました。

sen.j: かき氷の上に黒糖蜜、練乳、ドライフルーツなどのトッピングを乗せたあと、まん中にくぼみを作って、生卵の黄身を割り入れたものである。
sen.e: This is shaved ice having black syrup, condensed milk or dried fruits on top with a raw egg yolk cracked in a dent in the center.
This is shaved ice having black syrup, condensed milk or dried fruits on top with a raw egg yolk cracked into a dent in the center.
This is shaved ice having black syrup, condensed milk or dried fruits on top with a raw egg yolk cracked into a dent in the center.

sen.j: 中国語で月見は「賞月」という言い方が普通であり、「月見」は日本語からの借用と考えられる。
sen.e: In Chinese, Tsukimi is usually expressed as '賞月 (viewing moon),' so '月見' is considered to be borrowed from Japanese.
In Chinese, Tsukimi is usually expressed as '賞月 (viewing moon),' so '月見' is considered to be borrowed from Japanese.
In Chinese, Tsukimi is usually expressed as '賞月 (viewing moon),' so '月見' is considered to be borrowed from Japanese.

sen.j: （中国語は動詞―名詞の語順であり、「月見」のような名詞―動詞の語順は本来は用いない）
sen.e: (Chinese has word order as verb-noun, so word order as noun-verb such as '月見 (moon viewing)' is normally not used.)
(Chinese uses the verb-noun word order, so the word order as noun-verb such as '月見 (moon viewing)' is generally not used.)
(Chinese uses the verb-noun word order, so the word order as noun-verb such as '月見 (moon viewing)' is generally not used.)
